Time_Annotation: Its precursor formed to the northwest of Christmas Island on 5 January, drifting slowly southwards. The system reached cycle intensity at 00:00 UTC on 7 January, receiving the name Chris. On 9 January, Chris passed 90°E and moved into the Météo-France area of responsibility, where it was renamed Damia.

Main_Event_Annotation: The text indicates that the system became the strongest tropical cyclone on record in the South-West Indian Ocean, clearly categorizing it as a tropical cyclone.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: In August, a typhoon struck near Wenzhou, China, killing 50,000 people.[5]
In September, a typhoon killed 1,000 people and left US$20 million in damage when it struck Japan and sank the SS Kiche Maru.[10]
In November, typhoon struck Tacloban, Philippines, killing 15,000 people.
Also, on November 26, a typhoon struck Palau, killing two people.[3]

Total_Summary_Buildings_Damaged.Total_Buildings_Damaged_Annotation: The text describes extensive damage to numerous individual structures (e.g., CNN Center, Georgia World Congress Center, Omni Hotel, etc.) but does not provide an aggregate total number of damaged buildings.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: CNN Center was severely damaged, including shattered windows.
The Georgia World Congress Center sustained serious damage and later experienced flooding while hosting events.
The Omni Hotel was noted as having sustained serious damage, particularly to the skywalk between its two towers over Andrew Young International Boulevard.
The facades of the Georgia Dome were damaged during basketball games; later panels were ripped and holes appeared in its roof.
A Philips Arena parking garage had its facade damaged while hosting basketball games.
The Ritz Carlton had windows blown out.
The Westin Peachtree Plaza experienced blown-out windows that continued to fall for days, leading to pedestrian closures.
The Georgia-Pacific Building had windows blown out.
SunTrust Plaza had windows blown out and more than 60 people had to be relocated out of their offices.
The Equitable Building sustained damage with blown-out windows, with a note that 300 windows were affected at that location.
Georgia State University had windows blown out; additionally, its associated Rialto Theatre later sustained roof damage.
The Tabernacle—a former church with notable stained glass—had its windows blown out.
The historic Rialto Theatre at Georgia State University sustained roof damage causing water damage inside.
Grady Hospital reported window damage and a power outage.
The King Memorial MARTA station was damaged and trains were rerouted as a result.
In Cabbagetown, a brick loft building lost part of its roof and a portion of its top (fifth) floor.
A building at The Stacks on Boulevard was damaged; although search and rescue personnel could not enter, all occupants were accounted for.
At the nearby Philips Arena itself, damage occurred to the exterior even though attendees noticed little disruption.
Over 20 homes were completely destroyed.

Total_Summary_Deaths.Total_Deaths_Annotation: No explicit total number of deaths was mentioned in the content.

Total_Summary_Displaced.Total_Displaced_Annotation: While no aggregate displacement total is provided, the text notes that more than 60 people at SunTrust Plaza had to be relocated from their offices.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: SunTrust Plaza: more than 60 people had to be relocated out of their offices.

Total_Summary_Injuries.Total_Injuries_Annotation: The content does not provide a total injury count; it only notes specific instances of injuries treated at different locations.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: Grady Hospital: Many of the injured were taken there and treated for cuts due to falling glass.
At the nearby Philips Arena, twenty-seven people were treated for injuries.

Total_Summary_Insured_Damage.Total_Insured_Damage_Annotation: No information regarding insured damage was mentioned in the content.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage_Annotation: The content states that the tornado was the most expensive in Atlanta history, costing a half-billion dollars in raw U.S. dollars after the 1999 Oklahoma City tornado.

Time_Annotation: The narrative describes the moment 'when the tornado hit' and later notes that President Bush declared a major disaster on March 20 [75]. Although CNN’s broadcasting changes (e.g., resuming at 6 am EDT) are mentioned, no explicit start or end date for the tornado event is provided.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text references raw U.S. dollars and mentions federal and state emergency responses (e.g., declarations by President Bush and state agencies), indicating the event occurred in the United States.
Main_Event_Annotation: The text explicitly states 'when the tornado hit', clearly identifying the main event as a tornado.
Hazards_Annotation: Descriptions of shattered and blown-out windows, panels ripped from building exteriors, and fallen trees point to wind damage, which is consistent with a tornado event according to the provided hazard association.

Hazards_Annotation: The text explains that droughts in Chile are linked to low amounts of snow accumulation in the Andes, supporting the hazard identification as 'Drought.'

Time_Annotation: The article notes that 'Based on the astronomical definition, winter begins at the winter solstice, which in 2014 occurred on December 21, and ends at the March equinox, which in 2015 occurred on March 20.' It also mentions that wintry weather was experienced as early as mid-November and highlights the months of January–March as particularly wintry.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The text states that a period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States and cites specific locations such as Pensacola, Florida; Buffalo, New York; Boston; Arkansas; and Oklahoma, indicating that the United States was affected.
Main_Event_Annotation: The description of the winter as 'frigid' and the report of temperatures dropping 15 to 35°F below average along with the mention of a polar vortex and record-breaking snowfall support classifying this event under Extreme Temperature.
Hazards_Annotation: The article describes very frigid conditions, significant drops in temperature, and persistent cold weather, which aligns with the Cold Spell hazard under the Extreme Temperature category.

Time_Annotation: The article notes, 'Nonetheless, in most of the Hunter Basin, including Newcastle, 1980 was the driest year ever recorded. In some stations on the South Coast it was the driest since 1888,' which anchors the extreme weather conditions to 1980.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Multiple references such as 'southeastern Australia', 'eastern Australia', 'Canberra', 'New South Wales', 'South Australia', 'western Victoria', and 'northern Tasmania' indicate that the affected country is Australia.
Main_Event_Annotation: The text describes that 'many stations in the Mallee and adjacent parts of South Australia were completely rainless throughout the 1979/1980 summer' and states that 'drought again set in over the eastern coastal belt between Bundaberg and Hobart', culminating in 1980 being 'the driest year ever recorded', clearly identifying the main event as a drought.
Hazards_Annotation: Indicators such as completely rainless stations, Sydney receiving only 15 millimetres with imposed water restrictions, and the record dryness throughout 1980 support the hazard being drought.

Time_Annotation: The text notes that 'the May to August period was exceptionally wet over Victoria (except East Gippsland), inland New South Wales and South Australia. A constant flow of powerful lows made this period the wettest on record over Victoria, and the Murray Basin experienced major flooding in August.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Multiple parts of the text reference affected regions: 'January saw the most active monsoon since 1974 over Queensland', 'In western Tasmania, however, unusually hot and dry conditions led to a very rare fire in the wet forests near Zeehan', 'In New South Wales, January was dry, but February saw very heavy rains that temporarily broke the long drought', and 'the May to August period was exceptionally wet over Victoria (except East Gippsland), inland New South Wales and South Australia.'
Main_Event_Annotation: The description that 'the Murray Basin experienced major flooding in August' supports the classification of the event as Flood.
Hazards_Annotation: The heavy rainfall during May to August and the resulting 'major flooding' in the Murray Basin clearly indicate a flood hazard as per the Main_Event--Hazard association table.
